options.fig.cap: Sun exposure is a confounding variable because it is related to both response and explanatory variables.

options.fig.cap: Examples of simple random, stratified, and cluster sampling. In this figure, simple random sampling was used to randomly select the 18 cases.
options.label: unnamed-chunk-15

options.fig.cap: Examples of simple random, stratified, and cluster sampling. In the top panel, simple random sampling was used to randomly select the 18 cases. In the middle panel, stratified sampling was used: cases were grouped into strata, and then simple random sampling was employed within each stratum. In the bottom panel, cluster sampling was used, where data were binned into nine clusters, and three of the clusters were randomly selected.
options.label: unnamed-chunk-13

options.fig.cap: In this figure, cluster sampling was used, where data were binned into nine clusters, and three of the clusters were randomly selected.
options.label: unnamed-chunk-35

options.fig.cap: Blocking using a variable depicting patient risk. Patients are first divided into low-risk and high-risk blocks, then each block is evenly divided into the treatment groups using randomization. This strategy ensures an equal representation of patients in each treatment group from both the low-risk and high-risk categories.
options.label: unnamed-chunk-12
